title: Business Live: FTSE 100 closes up; Sterling down - BBC News
summary: business groups call for brexit clarity .
pendragon shares slide on profit warning .

documents.title: goodnight
text: that 's it for tonight on business live .
we 'll be back bright and early at 06:00 on tuesday morning .
do join us for all the latest breaking news and analysis from the business world .

documents.title: us stocks retreat
text: the dow jones ended flat at 23,349.7 , a 0.09 % - or 21-point - rise .
the s & p 500 fell 0.4 % , or 10 points , to 2,564.98 , and tech-heavy nasdaq fell 3.79 % , or 0.6 points , to 6,586.8 .

documents.title: look out , paypal
text: google is challenging paypal with a new service called pay with google , that aims to make it easier for online shoppers to checkout on websites .
you might be used to using paypal to pay for things online , so that you do n't need to give merchants your financial details .
google is doing the same thing - if you are using an android phone or the chrome web browser , google will automatically send your billing information to the merchant .
the internet giant has already got 15 partners on launch , and will soon be adding well known brands like just eat , hungryhouse , stubhub , airbnb and deliveroo to its service .

documents.title: is it just incompetence ?
text: the author of a report in 2013 about rbs ' global restructuring group says that the financial conduct authority needs to do more .
`` banks do not treat their customers inappropriately , bankers do , '' said lawrence tomlinson .

`` the authorities should look at whether these bankers ' behaviour is incompetent or criminal - either way , whoever allowed the scandal at grg to occur should not be allowed to work in the sector or enable similar ethos and culture to enter other banking institutions . ''

documents.title: oil prices steady
text: oil prices remained steady on monday , supported by supply disruptions in iraq denting exports , as well as us drilling rates dropping to their lowest since june .
brent crude settled at $ 57.37 ( £ 43.45 ) a barrel , down 38 cents , while west texas intermediate ( wti ) crude ended up 6 cents at $ 51.90 a barrel .

documents.title: human rights inquiry
text: prosecutors in new york are investigating the weinstein company , following allegations of sexual assault made against film producer harvey weinstein .

a subponea has been issued , seeking all documents , records and correspondence related to complaints of sexual harassment or discrimination from the studio , which is headquartered in new york city .
it also demands to know how complaints were handled and whether formal investigations were launched , and if not , why not .
`` no new yorker should be forced to walk into a workplace ruled by sexual intimidation , harassment , or fear , '' said new york attorney general eric schneiderman .
`` if sexual harassment or discrimination is pervasive at a company , we want to know . ''

documents.title: netflix selling bonds
text: netflix is hoping to raise $ 1.6bn ( £ 1.21bn ) to fund investments into new original tv shows and movies by selling bonds .
the online entertainment streaming service will be needed to help fund a growing $ 7-8bn budget for new content in 2018 .
netflix saw stronger-than-expected subscriber growth in the third quarter .

the service operates on a model that requires netflix to invest in content upfront in order to keep subscribers loyal , meaning that netflix continues to have growing negative free cash outflows , according to the ft .

documents.title: t-mobile goes for video
text: in a bid to avoid speculation about a possible merger with rival sprint , t-mobile us decided not to have its usual quarterly earnings call with investors , and instead put out a video message on youtube .

`` with all the rumours and speculation out there , we decided we wanted to make sure you all saw and focused on our q3 results , and not just on the rumours and speculation that seem to fill the news every day , '' said chief executive john legere .
the mobile operator reported record service revenues of $ 7.6bn ( £ 5.76bn ) and said that it was t-mobile 's `` best q3 ever '' .
t-mobile also reported $ 10bn in revenues , up 8 % , record net cash provided by operating activities of $ 2.4bn , up 36 % , and record free cash flow of $ 921m , up 59 % .

documents.title: toymakers under pressure
text: hasbro shares have tumbled 9.4 % after the toymaker projected lower sales growth than expected for the fourth quarter of 2017 - a key holiday shopping period .
barbie doll maker mattel 's shares fell , down 2.7 % to $ 15.53 .
both hasbro and mattel have been under pressure since toys r us filed for bankruptcy protection in the us and canada in september .

documents.title: philips brushes up on china
text: strong demand for its electric toothbrushes in china helped philips to boost sales by 4 % to €4.1bn in the third quarter .
the dutch firm , which spun off its lighting division last year to focus on medical devices and healthcare products , recorded double-digit growth in china .
that helped make up for flat sales in north america and a 6 % slide in western europe .
chief executive frans van houten says : `` we are very optimistic about our opportunities in china .
our toothbrushes continue to sell very well , while the growth of private hospitals diminishes the risk of government preferring domestic suppliers . ''

documents.title: etsy shares down
text: one of the losers on the nasdaq is etsy , a popular online marketplace for handmade artisan goods .
its shares have fallen nearly 4 % to $ 15.74 each following the news that amazon is launching the handmade gift shop .
the handmade gift shop aims to promote thousands of products by independent sellers and small businesses for the holiday season .

documents.title: wall street wilts in afternoon trade
text: when wall street opened a few hours ago , the main indexes were all at fresh highs .
but it 's well into the afternoon now and some of the shine has come off the markets ' performance .
the dow jones is the only one still in positive territory , up just 0.04 % on the day at 23,338.76 .
but the broader s & p 500 is down 0.06 % at 2,573.54 , while the tech-focused nasdaq is 0.15 % lower at 6,619.12 .

documents.title: back to the ( clean ) future ?
text: london mayor sadiq khan wants the government to implement further measures to help those affected by the city 's new traffic charge , known as the t-charge and aimed at diesel and petrol vehicles registered before 2006 .
he wants a new clean air act , similar to those implemented in 1956 and 1993 , to improve air quality in london
from today , there is now a £ 10 daily fee for those who drive more polluting vehicles in the congestion charging zone , on top of the existing £ 11.50 congestion charge .
but the clean air london group says mr khan should ban all diesel vehicles .

documents.title: socgen pauses brexodus
text: societe generale will wait for more clarity on brexit before deciding whether to move staff away from london , chief executive frederic oudea said .
the french bank has previously said it was considering moving 400 corporate and investment banking jobs to paris ahead of the uk 's departure from the eu .
the bank has 2,000 jobs in investment banking in london , mr oudea said earlier this year .

documents.title: seeking 'justice ' from rbs
text: the grg action group continues to call for the financial conduct authority to publish its full report on rbs ' treatment of small businesses .

the group , which represents more than 500 uk businesses , believes that the procedures set out by the bank for obtaining redress are `` inadequate '' and that the complaints process `` fails to address the issue of consequential loss '' facing many businesses .
`` far from drawing a line under this affair , today 's report is just the start of the long journey to justice for grg 's victims , '' said the grg action group .
`` it remains our belief that publication of this summary report is insufficient .
`` if anything , today 's findings solidify the case for having the fca 's report published in full so that the bank 's misdemeanours can be properly scrutinised . ''

documents.title: breakinglandmark fraud case
text: a former hsbc banker has been found guilty of defrauding cairn energy in a $ 3.5bn currency trade in 2011 .
us prosecutors said mark johnson , who was hsbc 's head of global cash foreign exchange trading , schemed to ramp up the price of the sterling before executing a trade for cairn .
his actions made millions for hsbc , at cairn 's expense .

documents.title: universal credit
text: an emergency debate on universal credit will take place tomorrow , the house of commons has announced on twitter .
universal credit replaces six benefits and merges them into one payment .
currently , at least a quarter of claimants have to wait for a month and a half for the first payment .
the speaker has approved the application .
emergency debate on # universalcredit will take place tomorrow and will last 3 hours
the idea is good , but that 6 week wait must be a killer for people.dwp dont help , they treat people like shit .
will they see sense and halt this misery now ?
@ twitterid @ twitterid
good to hear - hope there is a positive outcome to the debate .
stop this cruel treatment of people & families not in my name
we had 5 hours and a select committee meeting before hand last week .
the conclusion payments should be made quicker my honourable friend
when is it pencilled in for ?

documents.title: kaspersky opens up antivirus
text: russian cybersecurity firm kaspersky lab will allow third parties to analyse its antivirus software , in a bid to squash accusations that its software has been used to spy for the kremlin .
`` we want to show how we 're completely open and transparent .
we 've nothing to hide , '' said company founder eugene kaspersky .
`` cybersecurity has no borders , but attempts to introduce national boundaries in cyberspace is counterproductive and must be stopped .
we need to reestablish trust in relationships between companies , governments and citizens . ''
kaspersky antivirus software has been banned by all us government agencies following accusations that nation state hackers used the software to steal information from the nsa .

documents.title: fca 'making excuses '
text: rgl management , which was formed for the purpose of suing rbs over its treatment of small businesses , says that the financial conduct authority is not doing enough .
`` the fca is making excuses in its interim report as to why it can not bring the bank to justice , which does nothing to help redress the devastation inflicted on business owners by rbs .
`` if the fca can not , or will not , take action against the bank then it is important for distressed businesses and individuals to seek justice in the courts .
`` rgl management is the only group ready to do so , with expertise , funding and lawyers in place . ''

documents.title: london ends flat
text: the ftse 100 has closed flat at 7,524.4 points - just 1.2 points higher , following a day of very little movement .
the biggest faller was mediclinic after spire healthcare rejected its takeover bid , while gkn topped the risers , jumping 5.1 % .
meanwhile , the ftse 250 fell 0.1 % to 20,131.5 , with spire jumping 15.2 % .

documents.title: bidding war
text: amazon says it has received 238 proposals from cities in north america that wish to host the retail giant 's second headquarters .
the bids come from 43 us states , as well as three mexican states , seven canadian provinces , as well as the district of columbia and puerto rico .
amazon plans to invest $ 5bn ( £ 3.8bn ) and create 50,000 new jobs at the new headquarters , which will be a `` full equal '' to its seattle base .

documents.title: labour calls for judge-led inquiry
text: bill esterson , labour 's shadow business minister , has called for a judge-led enquiry into the treatment of small businesses by rbs .
the news of a police investigation last week is also an important step in ensuring the truth is discovered as part of a full and transparent process , '' he says .
`` trust between small businesses and our financial institutions needs to be restored because their relationship is key to the success of the uk economy . ''

documents.title: 'enron in the making '
text: no bitcoin for prince alwaleed bin talal , thanks very much .
the saudi billionaire , who owns investment firm kingdom holding , was scathing about cryptocurrencies in a cnbc interview today : `` i just do n't believe in this bitcoin thing .
i think it 's going to implode one day - it 's enron in the making , '' he says .
`` this thing does not make sense .
it 's unregulated .
it 's not under the control of the u.s. federal reserve or any other central bank . ''
author: Chris Johnston
Business reporter, BBC News

documents.title: wall street struggles
text: us shares are now struggling after the s & p 500 opened at a new record high earlier , following a `` perfect week '' .
the dow jones is at 23,349.7 points , up just 21 points or 0.1 % , while the s & p is becalmed at 2,575 .
the tech-heavy nasdaq is the worst performer , down 0.2 % at 6,616.19 points .

documents.title: deripaska prices en+ shares
text: aluminium and power producer en+ hopes to raise about $ 1.5bn ( £ 1.1bn ) with a london flotation that would mark one of the biggest russian listings in britain since the annexation of crimea in 2014 .
the company , which will remain majority owned by russian billionaire oleg deripaska ( today set a price range of $ 14 to $ 17 a share , valuing the company at between $ 7bn and $ 8.5bn ( £ 6.5bn ) .

the ipo is expected to measure investor appetite for russian assets given that it will be one of the first major listings by a russian firm since tensions between moscow and the west started to sour following the annexation of the crimea peninsula from ukraine nearly three years ago .
en+ last week appointed former uk energy minister lord barker as an independent chairman to its board .
mr deripaska also founded aluminium giant uc rusal and is the biggest shareholder in russian car maker gaz group .

documents.title: morgan responds to fca report
text: nicky morgan , who chairs the treasury select committee , says : it has taken the fca too long to publish its summary of the skilled persons ' report , so this is not before time .
the committee has put in place an arrangement to ensure maximum possible transparency is brought to this issue .
when its independent adviser reports back later this week , the committee will consider whether further steps are required . ''

documents.title: european commission investigating german cars
text: the european commission says it carried out inspections at the premises of several german car manufacturers today .
the ec is concerned the car manufacturers may have violated eu antitrust rules that prohibit cartels and restrictive business practices .
this follows an inspection of one car manufacturer by the ec on monday 16 october .
`` inspections are a preliminary step in investigations of suspected anti-competitive practices , '' said the ec .

`` the fact that the commission carries out inspections does not mean that the inspected companies are guilty of anti-competitive behaviour , nor does it prejudge the outcome of the investigation itself . ''

documents.title: rbs chief : 'report backs up worst allegations not upheld '
text: ross mcewan , the chief executive of rbs has given a telephone press conference .
here are some highlights :
emphasised that rbs believes this report backs up that the worst allegations have not been upheld
he apologised - in similar terms to the statement
on whether some of the staff are still there from the 2008 era : some have left and some are still within grg
said the fca could take action against the bank or individuals - no idea on timeline for the focused investigation
said will cooperate with police scotland - not had any contact yet
£ 115m of `` complex fee '' compensation offers have been made as of today
there are 938 complaints to be dealt with going back 10 years
said rbs acting on these as `` quickly as possible ''

documents.title: fca rbs report - some highlights
text: the financial watchdog 's report exonerated rbs on a number of counts :

documents.title: rbs says it has changed
text: rbs ' chief executive ross mcewan says he is pleased that the financial conduct authority report found that the most serious allegations made against the bank were not upheld .

we have acknowledged for some time that mistakes were made and have apologised that we did not always provide the level of service and understanding we should have done for these customers in the aftermath of the financial crisis , '' he said .
the regulator has again confirmed that the remediation steps we announced in november to address concerns for customers are appropriate .
any customer who feels they were treated inappropriately whilst in grg should make use of the complaints process .
the culture , structure and way rbs operates today have all changed fundamentally since the period under review .
we have made significant changes to deal with the issues of the past , so that the bank can better support sme customers in financial difficulty whilst also protecting the bank 's capital . ''

documents.title: rbs share price
text: shares in rbs were down 2.4p at 280p in the wake of the announcement from the fca - above their lowest for the day .

documents.title: rbs grg - some background
text: rbs 's global restructuring group operated between 2005 and 2013 and at its peak handled 16,000 companies .
the unit would step in when businesses had missed a loan repayment , or had a notable dip in sales or profits , and was marketed as a turnaround specialist .
but the fca report found that companies placed in the group had little chance of getting out of it .
only 10 % returned to the main rbs bank intact .
at the end of 2014 , 69 % of firms were still in the successor to grg .

documents.title: rbs responds to fca findings
text: rbs says it welcomes the publication of the financial conduct authority 's report looking into the bank 's treatment of small business customers referred to its global restructuring group .
the bank said it could have managed the transition to grg better and should have better explained to customers any changes to the prices or complex fees it was charging .
as a result of the issues identified , rbs put in place a complaints process and an automatic refund of complex fees for small business customers who were clients of the bank between 2008-2013 .
the bank says it has made over £ 115m in refund offers and that the complaints procedure has received 939 complaints to date .

documents.title: fca rbs report
text: a reminder : rbs 's grg - global restructuring group - was supposed to be a specialist division that helped struggling businesses get back on their feet .

documents.title: fca considers further action against rbs
text: andrew bailey , fca chief executive , said : commercial lending activity is largely unregulated in the uk but given the seriousness of the allegations against rbs it was appropriate for us to look at their treatment of sme customers .
as we reported in november 2016 , while the most serious allegations were not upheld by the skilled person , the report did identify other concerns about the treatment of sme customers .
rbs has accepted that it did not meet the standards it set for itself which impacted on how it treated some of its sme customers .

`` rbs has since taken voluntary steps , such as its proactive review of complex fees , and setting up a complaints scheme for eligible sme customers , overseen by an independent monitor , sir william blackburne .
having considered documents and cases highlighted by the skilled person we agreed that rbs 's proposals , including to establish a complaints scheme , were appropriate steps .
we are investigating the matters arising from the skilled person 's report and are focussing on whether there is any basis for further action within our powers .
we can not comment any further on this . ''

documents.title: breakingfca reviews rbs ' treatment of businesses
text: the financial conduct authority has published a new report stating that while it does have some concerns over rbs ' treatment of small business customers in trouble , the most serious allegations made against the bank were not upheld .
`` rbs has accepted that it did not meet the standards it set for itself which impacted on how it treated some of its sme customers , '' said fca 's chief executive andrew bailey .

`` rbs has since taken voluntary steps , such as its proactive review of complex fees , and setting up a complaints scheme for eligible sme customers , overseen by an independent monitor , sir william blackburne .
`` having considered documents and cases highlighted by the skilled person we agreed that rbs 's proposals , including to establish a complaints scheme , were appropriate steps . ''

documents.title: firms 'are making investment decisions '
text: suella fernandes rejects the idea that companies are reluctant to make investment decisions until a brexit transition deal is struck .
she tells the world at one : `` we 've had lots of business and investment decisions made since brexit about the uk .

`` multi-national companies like google and facebook - goldman sachs as well - have all made significant business decisions to stay in the uk or expand their uk premises so i do n't think its fair to say that businesses are facing uncertainty and they do n't know what to do . ''

documents.title: businesses are looking forward brexit , says fernandes
text: suella fernandes , chairman of the european research group of conservative mps , tells the world at one that she would `` question the cbi 's position '' .
she says : `` they do n't represent all businesses .

there are many strong business voices who are looking forward to the freedoms that the uk will enjoy when it comes to coming out of the customs union - being free to set our own regulations when we 're out of the single market . ''
ms fernandes adds : `` i think what it comes down to is the fact that of course both sides want a great free trade agreement where we can continue our tariff free trade and commerce .
britain is a big customer of the european union .
`` but we also need to be clear , if that is n't possible then we have to be prepared for the wto option which by no means is not a disaster . ''
author: The World at One
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: business groups 'are not helping the consumer '
text: commenting on the letter from uk business group 's to brexit secretary david davis , tory mp jacob rees-mogg claims that the `` arch-remoaners '' such as the cbi are not representing the best interests of the consumer .
he tells lbc radio that they want no change in trade terms for a transition period which means people will not enjoy the benefits of brexit

`` what i want to see happen is , out of the customs union , cutting duties on food , clothing and footwear because these three things are a disproportionate amount of the budgets of the poorest people in society .
`` what seems to be happening at the moment is we 've got people putting the producer first , putting the interests of everybody ahead of the consumer . ''

documents.title: london shares treading water
text: there 's still very little movement on the key ftse 100 share index .
a short while ago it was at 7,526.81 , a tiny rise of about 4 points or 0.05 % .
the ftse 250 , however , is still down slightly .
it 's at 20,122.60 , up 24 points or 0.12 % .

documents.title: more bumpy skies for ryanair
text: irish independent reporter john mulligan tweets :
@ twitterid pilots set to demand big pay increases as unrest continues # aviation

documents.title: singapore caps car ownership
text: singapore has placed a cap on car ownership , preventing citizens from buying new vehicles until the policy is reviewed again in 2020 , reports bbc world service .
the city-state 's land transport authority said the lack of available land and planned investments in public transport justified the new policy .
the singaporean authorities have been controlling the amount of traffic by auctioning off the right to own a car .
singapore has more than 5.6 million people , but just 600,000 cars .
author: BBC World Service

documents.title: tune in to world at one
text: if you want to hear more from cbi boss carolyn fairbairn she 'll be on bbc radio 4 just after the top of the hour .
business groups have written to the government calling for more clarification .
we hear from the head of the cbi @ twitterid # wato
on hard brexit 1000s of uk will have to change how they operate putting 1000s jobs at risk , why does n't the bbc interview these businesses

documents.title: striking the best deal for firms
text: carolyn fairbairn says that businesses want to see a comprehensive and considered brexit deal struck for businesses .
she says : `` the principals that businesses said they want have been the same since the beginning - barrier free trade , easy regulation , no custom delays - these are the things that matter .
`` we need as much time as possible to talk about them so [ we need ] transition by december , that leaves the early part of next year to strike a great deal . ''

documents.title: another reason the pound 's down ?
text: here 's a different explanation from another analyst as to why cable - the pound-dollar exchange rate - has come under a bit of pressure .
according to the day 's figures from the cbi , uk business optimism is at its lowest level since july 2016 just after the brexit referendum result .
this , understandably , softened up sterling , dragging cable down by 0.2 % while halving the pound 's gains against the euro to just 0.1 % .

despite an unhappy set of banking stocks - and the latest signs of the household spending squeeze , this time in the form of pendragon 's profit warning -sterling 's losses helped the ftse eke out some early in the week growth , sending the uk index 0.2 % higher to 7535 .

documents.title: factory orders slow amid fall in business optimism
text: growth in uk factory orders slowed in october , according to a monthly survey from the confederation of british industry ( cbi ) .
the survey also found that optimism about business conditions fell , for the first time in a year .
meanwhile , sentiment about export prospects continued to rise , but at a slower pace .
growth in output , domestic orders and export orders also eased , although they were still above their long-run averages .

`` growth in output and orders are still above historical norms , and it 's encouraging that plans for spending on innovation and training are holding their own , '' cbi chief economist rain newton-smith said .
`` but we 've seen a general softening in manufacturing activity over the past three months , with the outlook for investment becoming more subdued , '' she added .

documents.title: sterling down against the dollar
text: the pound headed down against the dollar on monday morning .
the fall came after sterling received a boost on friday amid signs of progress in talks over the uk 's exit from the european union .
`` over the weekend we 've seen a lot of press indicating that there are divisions in the party , '' said jane foley , senior currency strategist at rabobank .
`` so there is this cloud of uncertainty , not just related to the progress of brexit talks but also to the divisions within the governing party . ''
the pound is down 0.14 % against the dollar at $ 1.3169 .
however , it 's up 0.14 % against the euro at 1.1212 .

documents.title: businesses implement brexit contingency plans
text: what about the people who work at companies who may have to relocate some of their operations to the european union ?
the cbi 's carolyn fairbairn says : `` these are very real human costs in terms of communities because the decisions that firms are taking , in a very practical way , are very real .
`` so i think that you are seeing contingency plans being drawn up .
some of them are being implemented now in some sectors .

`` i think in more firms they are being drawn up , ready to see what happens in december and hoping that there is real progress made then because that is how you keep jobs and investment in the uk and in the european union more generally . ''

documents.title: firms are planning for the worst case scenario
text: the cbi 's director general , carolyn fairbairn says that the real prize being sought by businesses post-brexit is a barrier-free trade deal for the long-term .
however , she says : `` they still do n't know whether that 's going to be the case , they 're having to plan on the worst case at the moment . ''
she adds : `` let 's have a transition deal , a one step transition that 's simple and on the basis of current rules so that those all-important trade talks can begin as soon as possible . ''

documents.title: aramco float 'on track '
text: saudi aramco will float next year as planned , its chief executive says , but did not reveal what everyone really wants to know : on which exchange .
`` we have always said that we will be listing in 2018 , and to be more specific , in the second half of 2018 , '' amin nasser tells cnbc .
`` the ipo is on track .
the listing venue will be discussed and shared in due course . ''
aramco is preparing to list about 5 % of its shares next year , but is yet to choose an overseas market .
mr nasser rejected a report that china was emerging as a frontrunner in a possible plan to delay the ipo and sell shares to sovereign wealth funds , cnbc added .

documents.title: uk and eu firms calls for speedier brexit deal
text: the cbi 's carolyn fairbairn says that companies understand that striking a deal between the uk and brussels is `` really tough '' , but she says it affects both british and european firms in terms of jobs and investment .
she tells the bbc : `` one of the big messages from firms is 'get on with it ' on both sides .
find a way to get an agreement by the end of the year on transition so we can have the all important proper trade talks about the final deal in the first half of next year . ''

documents.title: cbi boss calls for brexit transition deal by year end
text: carolyn fairbairn , director general of the cbi which is one of signatories of a letter to brexit secretary david davis , says the group is seeing a `` growing sense of urgency '' from business .
she tells the bbc : `` although there has been good progress made and friday was important , it is now only 17 months until the day the uk leaves the european union .
that is tomorrow for many firms and they are making plans now in response to what might be wto rules which could mean tariffs on food .
the services sector is n't covered at all so they are making decision today , right now , about investment .
`` this is real , this is urgent and a transition agreement by the end of the year would help enormously to keep investment and jobs in the country . ''

documents.title: johnson tells brussels to 'get on with it '
text: foreign secretary boris johnson has some sage advice for the powers that be in brussels about brexit talks .
i suggest humbly to our friends and partners in brussels to get on with it , '' he said in london on monday .
he added : `` they should grip it , go and get on with it and start thinking about the future .
`` i am sure we can both think very creatively and very positively about how to come to arrangements that suit both our constituents on both sides of the channel . ''

documents.title: households expect interest rate rise
text: more than 40 % of households expect the interest rate to rise before 2018 .
the ihs markit household finance index said that the number of consumers surveyed in october expect a move by the bank of england by the end of the year compared to just 12 % in september .
it said : `` a clear majority of uk households forecast a rise in the next year ( 80 % ) , up from 52 % in september .
the survey data suggests that the majority of uk households have shifted their expectations , and now predict a base rate hike in the near-term . ''
the bank of england will announce its interest rate decision on 2 november when it will also publish its quarterly inflation report .

documents.title: merrill investigated in previous cases
text: the fca says that while bank of america merrill lynch was open and co-operative in assisting in the investigation and quickly took steps to remedy the failure , it says the bank was the subject of two earlier and related transaction reporting cases .
mark steward , the fca 's executive director of enforcement and market oversight , says : effective market oversight depends on accurate and timely reporting of transactions . ''
he adds : `` it is vital that reporting firms ensure their transaction reporting systems are tested as fit for purpose , adequately resourced and perform properly .
there needs to be a line in the sand .
we will continue to take appropriate action against any firm that fails to meet requirements . ''

documents.title: breakingmerrill lynch £ 34.5m for reporting failures
text: the financial conduct authority ( fca ) has fined bank of america merrill lynch £ 34.5m for failing to report 68.5 million exchange traded derivative transactions in early february last year .
the fca said : `` reporting exchange traded derivative transactions helps authorities assess and address the risk inherent in financial systems caused by a lack of transparency .
`` the reporting requirement was one of the key reforms introduced following the financial crisis in 2008 to improve transparency within financial markets . ''

documents.title: the inequality of globalisation
text: more from the commission of global transformation 's robert johnson who says that the alternative for germany , marine le pen , the catalans and the election of donald trump are evidence of people 's frustration at the effects of globalisation and behaviour of governments .

he tells the bbc 's today programme : `` there are a whole lot of people who lost their homes , a whole lot of people who experienced collapse of their wealth and yet they feel the banks got bailed out with not much constriction or change in the rules and everybody went back to getting their huge bonuses very quickly . ''
in this light then , what about us president donald trump 's plan to roll back on bank regulation ?
`` i think it 's misguided , '' mr johnson says .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: t-charge 'only part of the story '
text: on today the man behind the t-charge , london mayor sadiq khan , says more needs to e done to tackle all kinds of pollution .
we think half the pollution comes from vehicles , i 'm taking steps to address that - but the government needs a new clean air act for the 21st century to deal with the other half .
issues like wood-burning stoves where there are things that are being burnt that should n't be .
we need a diesel scrappage scheme , but also we need to make sure the government gives cities and regions the power , resources we need to clean up the air in our cities . '
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: big strides at dr martens
text: iconic footwear brand dr martens has seen sales and profits take a big leap forward , helped by its performance in asia .
group sales jumped by 25 % to £ 290.6m in the year to march 31 , while operating profit rose by 27 % to £ 37.5m .
but dr martens ' asian business saw sales soar by 43 % to £ 66.4m as it opened five new stores in japan and two in hong kong .
in japan , sales were up 88 % to £ 22m .
however , dr martens highlighted challenging trading conditions in the us and `` potential headwinds following brexit '' as stumbling blocks for growth .

documents.title: hsbc announces new india boss
text: hsbc has named jayant rikhye as the new chief executive of its india division .
he will take over the role from stuart milne on 1 december who will move to a new role after heading the india operation for five years .
mr rikhye has been with hsbc for 28 years and is currently head of international , asia-pacific .

documents.title: brewery numbers bubble up
text: there are now more than 2,000 breweries in the uk for the first time since the 1930s , according to accountancy group uhy hacker young .
there 's been a 64 % increase in breweries over the past five years propelled by increased sales of artisan beers in pubs and supermarkets .
james simmonds of uhy hacker young , said : `` the craft beer boom has reversed around 70 years of consolidation in the brewing industry .
there is plenty of growth still to come . ''

documents.title: quel fromage !
text: good news of stinky cheese lovers in china - the government has reversed a ban on mould-ripened cheeses .
imports of camembert , brie and roquefort can begin again after it was determined that bacterial cultures used for the production of these cheeses were not harmful to consumers ' health .

`` it 's a real relief , '' says vincent marion , co-founder of cheese republic , an online cheesemonger that sells to china : `` it is now written in black and white that this category of cheese is legally importable .
so it is very positive for the french and european dairy industry . ''

documents.title: what does pendragon say about uk economy ?
text: so far on monday there 's been little movement in the ftse 100 which is down just 0.13 % .
the pound 's also pretty steady - it 's up by 0.04 % against the dollar at $ 1.3194 and 0.22 % against the euro at 1.1212 euros .
however , those figures ignore a warning sign about the uk economy , according to one analyst .
there were signs of weakness in the uk economy that both currency and index seemed to ignore this monday .

british car dealership chain pendragon plunged nearly 20 % after warning on full-year profit , the company struggling with the declining demand for new cars and the impact this has had on the used car market .
it 's the latest sign of retail-woe in the uk , especially among companies dealing with big ticket items , as the household spending squeeze continues .

documents.title: transmission tower giant to float
text: the uk largest owner of mobile , tv and radio towers is set to float on the london stock exchange in a deal valuing the business at £ 6bn .
arqiva is owned by the canada pension plan investment board and macquarie and aims to raise £ 1.5bn to pay down debt .
the company works with the like of the bbc , itv , channel 4 and channel 5 .
its owners had attempted to sell the business privately before opting for an initial public offering ( ipo ) .
arqiva says it is well positioned to provide shareholders with `` generous '' dividends and expects to pay out £ 195m this year .
in the year to june , revenue reached £ 943.8m .

documents.title: keeping the wolf from the door
text: it has warned on profits and is at risk of breaching its banking covenants but there is a little light on the horizon for construction and services group interserve .
shares in the company rose 2.81 % to 78.65p after it announced that it has won a £ 140m contract with the bbc to continue providing facilities services until 2023 .
`` when you 're at risk of breaking banking covenants , there is nothing like some contract wins to grow yourself out of trouble , '' says neil wilson , senior market analyst at etx capital .

documents.title: spire shares soar
text: shares in spire healthcare have shot up by 11 % after it rejected a £ 1.3bn takeover offer form south africa 's mediclinic , saying that the offer `` significantly undervalues '' the business and its prospects '' ( see earlier post ) .

documents.title: pendragon shares driven lower
text: shares in car dealership company pendragon have taken a dive this morning .
they 're down by 15 % - driven lower by the profits warning the company issued at 07:00am ( see earlier post ) .

documents.title: asian market update
text: let 's check in on how other asian markets are performing so far .
in seoul the kospi closed at a new high on monday at 2,490.05 , that 's a rise of 0.51 points or 0.02 % .
in hong kong the hang seng is still open and trading lower at 28,338.31 , a fall of 148.93 points or 0.52 % .
meanwhile the shanghai composite index is up by 0.25 % or 8.48 points at 3,378.65 .

documents.title: a new world order ?
text: is capitalistion dead ?
and if so , how should the world order change ?

the commission of global transformation 's robert johnson says we need to gain a better understanding of the global financial system and `` bounding '' the sector 's behavior `` so they do n't feel like they have one-sided bets - heads i win , tails you lose '' .

documents.title: london stock markets diverge at open
text: the ftse 100 has opened 2.47 points higher at 7,525.70 .
however , the ftse 250 is down 9.13 points to 20,137.75 in opening trade .

documents.title: pendragon hit by fall in demand for new cars
text: pendragon - which owns the stratstone and evans halshaw car dealerships - has said it expects a fall in demand to affect its annual results .

`` the decline in demand for new cars and the consequent used car price correction has impacted this year 's profit outturn and we anticipate that our full year underlying profit before tax will now be approximately £ 60m , '' it said in an interim trading statement covering 1 july to 20 october .
however , it added it expected a `` resumption of growth in profits in 2018 '' .

`` during the quarter as consumer confidence waned we experienced significant market pressures we expect the new car market to continue to decline this year and the first half of next year as car manufacturers continue to adjust to the reduced level of demand for new cars . ''

documents.title: nikkei hits 21-year high
text: japanese stocks hit their highest level since 1996 on monday after exit polls indicated prime minister shinzo abe had won a clear election victory .
the nikkei climbed nearly 1 % , extending its recent winning streak .
the liberal democratic party ( ldp ) coalition is set to retain its two-thirds majority , suggesting mr abe 's economic policies will continue .
the yen hit a three-month low against the us dollar , helping boost shares of japanese exporters .
a weaker yen tends to lift the shares of export firms because it makes their products cheaper to overseas customers .

documents.title: mediclinic offers cash and shares for spire
text: mediclinic international already owns 29.9 % of spire healthcare and has offered 298.6p in cash and shares for the business .

private hospital group spire has been struggling and in september issued a profit warning after it was forced to set aside £ 27.6m to compensate hundreds of patients for botched of unnecessary breast operations by disgraced surgeon ian paterson .
on friday , its shares rose by nearly 5 % to 261.28p .

documents.title: spire healthcare rejects takeover offer
text: private hospital group spire healthcare has rejected a £ 1.3bn offer from south africa 's mediclinic , stating that the offer `` significantly undervalues '' the business and `` its prospects '' .

documents.title: globalisation - the beast of no nation
text: a group of economic bigwigs have come together to form the commission on global transformation and one of the issues it is responding to is the rise in global populism in the west .

robert johnson , the former chief economist of the us senate banking committee who helped establish the committee , tells the bbc 's today programme : `` right now we have a situation where globalisation is a beast of no nation .

it is tearing apart the inner workings of governments - how they manage to create broader prosperity , how they deal with equality because capital and technology have wings they can move anywhere they want around the world .
`` labour is more confined , the bargaining terms have changed .
politicians are begging companies not to go to countries where labour and environmental standards are less strong .

so we 're in a place right now where we need a system that 's responsive , rewrites the rules , as joe stiglitz one of our co-chairs often says , and puts forward an agenda that essentially the economy starts working for people again instead of the other way around . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: business is 'key ' to island 's success
text: business leaders on scotland 's islands have called for more to be done to improve the infrastructure and encourage young people to stay .
a survey of 275 island firms by the federation of small businesses ( fsb ) found 88 % said they faced challenges that mainland businesses do not .
the report identifies transport and affordable housing as priorities .
the scottish government said it was investing millions in digital connectivity , transport and housing .
david richardson , the fsb 's development manager for the highlands and islands , said prosperity was `` intertwined '' with the success of its local business community .
read the full story here

documents.title: what is the t-charge ?
text: let 's just spell out exactly what london 's new toxicity charge involves :
from monday 23 october , there will be a £ 10 daily fee for those who drive more polluting vehicles in the congestion charging zone , on top of the existing £ 11.50 congestion charge .
vehicles that do not comply with the euro iv exhaust standard must pay the charge .
the standard defines emissions limits for cars , vans , buses , coaches and lorries .
most vehicles registered before 2006 are likely to exceed these limits .
the zone will operate between 07:00 and 18:00 , monday to friday .

documents.title: planning ahead
text: britain 's biggest business group have come together to urge the government to spell out a brexit transition deal .
this is because , says ritu vohora on today , equities investment director at m & g , that `` businesses are struggling with certainty '' .
she says that companies plan four or five years in advance , and in fact many will now be preparing their budget for 2018 in terms of jobs and investments .
and because of this , it would be useful to know by christmas what the transition deal will look like .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: 'jury 's out ' on brexit effect
text: more now from british retail constortium boss helen dickinson on wake up to money
presenter sean farrington said the uk economy did n't suffer the big shock that many people were predicting after the brexit vote last year .
what 's the feeling now , he asked .

ms dickinson said : `` we 're seeing a little bit of inflation start to feed through , that is a function of the pound as a result of the vote , but i think from a general public , consumer point of view the jury 's out .

`` people really at the moment ca n't see that much different in their day to day lives and so what 's really important is that the government make sure that as those negotiations continue that that continues to be the case . ''
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: where now for abenomics ?
text: shinzo abe has been re-elected as japan 's prime minister , helped in part by an improvement in the country 's economy .
so is abenomics succeeding ?
seijiro takeshita , professor of management and information at the university of shizuoka , is n't convinced .

he says because of the first two arrows , on easing monetary policy and increasing government spending : `` we are seeing record levels of earnings by the exporters which was very much induced by the first two arrows of abenomics but the problem is this excessive profit really is n't sinking into the individual .
in other words , we are not seeing the wage rise . ''
japan is still highly indebted , and professor takeshita says that although people do n't want to face it , taxes will probably need to rise .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: prioritise ports ?
text: the five biggest business lobby groups are calling for an urgent brexit transition deal , or they warn the uk risks losing jobs and investment .
in a joint letter being sent to brexit secretary david davis , the groups , including the institute of directors and cbi , will say time is running out .
sources told the bbc the letter is still in draft form , but will be sent in the next day or two
on wake up to money the boss of the british retail consortium , helen dickinson , says that retailers have `` exactly the same concerns '' as the bodies which have signed the letter .

she says what 's really important now is that from chancellor philip hammond 's budget point of view is that `` he 's putting some money aside to invest in the ports , the customs , in making sure that when it does come to an end that we as a country are ready for the new processes and procedures that need to be in place that our ports '' in order to ensure that we can bring goods across borders easily .

documents.title: toshiba warns on profits
text: toshiba has warned that it will fall into a loss for the interm period and the full year .

the struggling japanese conglomerate has revised down its net income forecast to a loss of 60bn yen ( £ 399m ) for the first six months of the year , compared to expectations of a 140bn yen net profit .
for the year year , toshiba expects 110bn yen loss compared to previous expectations of 230bn yen .

documents.title: toxicity charge could be 'final straw '
text: more on london 's new toxicity charge now which mainly applies to diesel and petrol vehicles registered before 2006 .
it covers the same area as the existing congestion charge zone , bumping the cost to £ 21.50 for those affected .
on wake up to money , denise beedell , development manager for the greater london federation of small business is asked what the new toxicity charge could mean for her members .
she says it 's a problem for small firms .
the cost of doing business in london is `` disproportionately high '' , she says .
most of the fsb members with older cars are hanging on to them .
`` it 's one more cost for them to add into the pot . ''
she says the fsb is worried that this will be the final straw for some of our members and `` this will take their business and therefore the jobs that go with it '' .
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: polluter pays ?
text: the news that a new charge for the most polluting petrol and diesel cars comes into force today in central london even makes it onto bbc world service
the toxicity or t-charge costs £ 10 a day , it reports .
this is in addition to a daily congestion charge levied in the british capital since 2003 .
air quality in london regularly breaks european pollution limits and the new charge is the latest step in trying to reduce the levels of deadly gases and particles in the city .
some health charities and environmental groups have welcomed the move but others say it does n't go far enough .
author: BBC World Service

documents.title: global growth drives up shares
text: the ftse 100 finished flat on friday at 7,523.23 - but it 's still only about 100 points behind the record high it hit earlier in the year .
in the us shares are reaching new records , driven in particular by tech stocks .
on wake up to money ritu vohora , equities investment director at m & g , is asked why shares are doing so well .
she attributes it to `` synchronised global growth '' .
companies ' earnings are improving from the us to the uk , in europe and in emerging markets she says .
the rise in shares is `` driven by better earnings and earnings are what you need for the rally to be sustainable '' , she says .

documents.title: good morning
text: today sees the introduction of the new toxicity charge for older , more polluting vehicles driving in london - we 'll bring the details of that , plus all the reaction and analysis .

also , it 's emerged that the uk 's five biggest business lobby groups have written to brexit secretary david davis , calling for an urgent brexit transition deal , or they warn the uk risks losing jobs and investment .
we 'll more on that and all latest business news as it breaks in , so do stay with us if you can .
